subject: ACM CSUR Call for Papers
body:
CALL FOR PAPERS ACM Computing Surveys Integration of computer science and engineering knowledge 2018 Journal Impact Factor: 6.131 Editor-in-Chief Sartaj Sahni, University of Florida ---------------------------------------------------------------------- Information For Contributors ACM Computing Surveys (CSUR) publishes comprehensive, readable tutorials and survey papers that give guided tours through the literature and explain topics to those who seek to learn the basics of areas outside their specialties. These carefully planned and presented introductions are also an excellent way for professionals to develop perspectives on, and identify trends in, complex technologies. Recent issues have covered image understanding, software reusability, and object and relational database topics. Both surveys and tutorials must develop a framework or overall view of an area that integrates the existing literature. Frequently, such a framework exposes topics that need additional research; a good Computing Surveys article can fill such a void, but that is not its major purpose. Basically, a Computing Surveys article answers the questions, "What is currently known about this area, and what does it mean to researchers and practitioners?" It should supply the basic knowledge to enable new researchers to enter the area, current researchers to continue developments, and practitioners to apply the results. Invitation The Editor-in-Chief (https://csur.acm.org/editorial.cfm) welcomes suggestions for topics and questions about contemplated submissions. Potential authors should consult the Author Guidelines at https://csur.acm.org/authors.cfm. For further information and to submit your manuscript, please visit https://csur.acm.org. ---------------------------------------------------------------------- Associate Editors * Vijay Atluri, Rutgers University * Chandrajit Bajaj, University of Texas at Austin * Azzedine Boukerche, University of Ottawa * Jonathan Bowen, London South Bank University * Longbing Cao, University of Technology Sydney * Sharat Chandran, Indian Institute of Technology * Jinjun Chen, Swinburne University of Technology * Yeh-Ching Chung, National Tsing Hua University * Antonio Corradi, Universit� di Bologna * Mario Dantas, Federal University of Juiz de Fora (UFJF) * Eliezer Dekel, IBM * Yuguang "Michael" Fang, University of Florida * Wen Gao, Peking University * Teofilo Gonzalez, University of California Santa Barbara * Mei Hong, Institute of Software * Paolo Ienne, �cole Polytechnique F�d�rale de Lausanne * S. Sitharama Iyengar, Florida International University * Samee U. Smith, The Johns Hopkins University * Ram Sriram, National Institute of Standards and Technology * Carlos A. Varela, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute * Shie-Yuan Wang, National Chiao Tung University * Damon Woodard, University of Florida * Yuanyuan Yang, Stony Brook University (SUNY) * Fran�ois Yvon, Universit� Paris-Sud * Albert Zomaya, University of Sydney ------------------------------------------------------------------------ To stop receiving emails about publishing in ACM journals, unsubscribe at: https://optout.acm.org/unsubscribe.cfm?re=foaad@calpoly.edu&rl=CFP Association for Computing Machinery 1601 Broadway, 10th Floor, New York, NY 10019, USA Copyright 2019, ACM, Inc. Call for Papers

CALL FOR PAPERS

ACM Computing Surveys
Integration of computer science and engineering knowledge

Editor-in-Chief
Sartaj Sahni, University of Florida


Information For Contributors

ACM Computing Surveys (CSUR) publishes comprehensive, readable tutorials and survey papers that give guided tours through the literature and explain topics to those who seek to learn the basics of areas outside their specialties. These carefully planned and presented introductions are also an excellent way for professionals to develop perspectives on, and identify trends in, complex technologies. Recent issues have covered image understanding, software reusability, and object and relational database topics.

Both surveys and tutorials must develop a framework or overall view of an area that integrates the existing literature. Frequently, such a framework exposes topics that need additional research; a good Computing Surveys article can fill such a void, but that is not its major purpose. Basically, a Computing Surveys article answers the questions, "What is currently known about this area, and what does it mean to researchers and practitioners?" It should supply the basic knowledge to enable new researchers to enter the area, current researchers to continue developments, and practitioners to apply the results.

Invitation

The Editor-in-Chief welcomes suggestions for topics and questions about contemplated submissions. Potential authors should consult the Author Guidelines.

For further information and to submit your manuscript, please visit csur.acm.org.
